bestBHT.bht: Paul endured immense suffering for his faith, facing beatings, stoning, and shipwrecks. These trials were not merely mentioned in passing, but they were experiences that deeply impacted him. The beatings with rods were a cruel and barbaric form of punishment, while the stoning he endured left him supposed to be dead. Despite facing multiple shipwrecks, including a treacherous night and day spent in the deep, Paul's steadfastness and resilience remained unwavering. His sufferings went beyond what was recorded in Luke's account, highlighting the extent of his hardships and the depth of his commitment to spreading the gospel.

Henry Alford: Thrice was I beaten with rods.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The beating by Roman magistrates at Philippi (Acts 16:23) is the only one recorded in Acts.
Thrice . . . shipwreck—before the shipwreck at Melita (Acts 16:23- :). Probably in some of his voyages from Tarsus.
Albert Barnes: This was a frequent mode of punishment among the ancient nations, and as Paul was often persecuted, he would be naturally subjected to this shameful punishment.

Had the assault been completed; had the history related that a stone was thrown, as it relates that preparations were made both by Jews and Gentiles to stone Paul and his companions; or even had the account of this transaction stopped without going on to inform us that Paul and his companions were aware of their danger and fled, a contradiction between the history and the Epistle would have ensued.

The supposition of some commentators that he spent his time on some rock in the deep; or of others that this means some deep dungeon; or of others that he was swallowed by a whale (that is, a big fish), like Jonah, shows the extent to which the fancy is often indulged in interpreting the Bible.
Marvin Vincent: Thrice I suffered shipwreck. The shipwreck at Malta, being later, is, of course, not referred to; so that no one of these three is on record."
A night and a day [νυχθημερον] . A compound term occurring only here in the New Testament, and rarely in later Greek.
Have I been in the deep [εν τω βυθω πεποιηκα] . Lit., I have made (spent) a night and a day in the deep.
John Calvin: It appears, that the Apostle suffered many things, of which no mention is made by Luke.
We have not, however, a complete narrative, nor is there mention made in it of every particular that occurred, but only of the principal things.
Truth is necessarily consistent; but it is scarcely possible that independent accounts, not having truth to guide them, should thus advance to the very brink of contradiction without falling into it.
Philip Schaff: Thrice was I beaten with rods, inflicted barbarously and with cruel aggravations.
Once was I stoned, when he was 'supposed to be dead.'
Thrice I suffered shipwreck, clinging to some plank and escaping with difficulty.
Archibald T. Robertson: Thrice was I beaten with rods (τρις ερραβδισθην). Roman (Gentile) punishment.
Once was I stoned (απαξ ελιθασθην). Once for all απαξ means.
Night and day (νυχθημερον) Rare word. Papyri give νυκτημαρ with the same idea (night-day).
John Gill: Thrice was I beaten with rods...once was I stoned...thrice I suffered shipwreck...a night and a day I have been in the deep."

This phrase may only signify that the ship in which he was was drove from the coast into the sea, and lost sight of the land for the space of a day and night, and lay floating about in the deep, which was reckoned very dangerous."
The word νυχθημερον, 'a night day,' signifies a whole natural day, consisting of a night and a day; and is an Hebraism, and answers to ערב ובקר, 'the evening and the morning,' which make a full day.
John Wesley: Thrice I have been shipwrecked — Before his voyage to Rome.
In the deep — Probably floating on some part of the vessel.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul endured immense suffering for his faith, facing beatings, stoning, and shipwrecks. These trials were not merely mentioned in passing, but they were experiences that deeply impacted him. The beatings with rods were a cruel and barbaric form of punishment, while the stoning he endured left him supposed to be dead. Despite facing multiple shipwrecks, including a treacherous night and day spent in the deep, Paul's steadfastness and resilience remained unwavering. His sufferings went beyond what was recorded in Luke's account, highlighting the extent of his hardships and the depth of his commitment to spreading the gospel.

Paul endured great sufferings for his faith, facing beatings, stoning, and shipwrecks. The beatings with rods were a cruel punishment inflicted upon him, while the stoning he experienced almost claimed his life. Despite this, Paul's unwavering commitment to spreading the gospel remained strong. He faced multiple shipwrecks, including spending a day and a night in the deep, floating on some part of the vessel. These hardships, not all mentioned in Luke's account, reveal the depth of Paul's trials and the strength of his devotion to his mission.

Paul's commitment to his faith led him to endure tremendous suffering. He was beaten with rods on three occasions, facing cruel punishment. He was stoned, coming close to losing his life. Paul also endured shipwrecks, including spending a day and a night in the deep. These experiences of physical pain and danger were a testament to his unwavering dedication to spreading the gospel. Even though some of his sufferings were not recorded, the extent of his trials reveals the depth of his devotion.

Paul's unwavering faith led him to face intense suffering. He endured beatings with rods on three occasions, cruelly inflicted upon him by Roman authorities. He was stoned, enduring a near-death experience. Paul also faced the dangers of shipwrecks, including spending a day and a night in the perilous deep. These tribulations, some of which were not recorded, demonstrate the depth of his commitment to spreading the gospel. Paul's enduring resilience and steadfastness in the face of hardship serve as an inspiration to believers.

Paul's unyielding faith led him to endure severe suffering, including beatings with rods and stoning. He faced the dangers of shipwrecks on multiple occasions, with one instance that left him spending a day and a night in the deep. These hardships, some of which were not recorded, exemplify the depth of Paul's commitment to his mission of spreading the gospel. His resilience and unwavering dedication serve as an inspiration to all believers, reminding us to remain steadfast in our faith despite challenging circumstances.
